articles.headline: How Netflix Keeps Finding Itself on the Same Side as Regulators
articles.snippet: The invisible hand of Netflix has been at work influencing policy and proposed mergers in the cable, broadband and media businesses.
articles.abstract: The invisible hand of Netflix has been at work influencing policy and proposed mergers in the cable, broadband and media businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whatever the outcome of the latest proposed mergers and acquisitions in the media industry, a clear winner has already emerged, and it’s not even a party to any of the deals: Netflix, the streaming television pioneer.

articles.headline: Colorado Killer James Holmes’s Notes: Detailed Plans vs. ‘a Whole Lot of Crazy’
articles.snippet: Prosecutors say the defendant was sane and methodical, planning his rampage with murderous intent. Defense lawyers say his writing brims with delusions that were the product of a profoundly diseased mind.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors say the defendant was sane and methodical, planning his rampage with murderous intent. Defense lawyers say his writing brims with delusions that were the product of a profoundly diseased mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — The spiral notebook is a road map to murder, filled with plans, diagrams and to-do lists that James E. Holmes laid out in scrupulous detail before carrying out a shooting rampage in a Colorado movie theater. In his own handwriting, he plans a “mass murder spree” and considers theaters and times to attack for “maximum casualties.” He also plots his own psyche with pages of self-diagnosis of what he calls his “broken mind.”

articles.headline: U.S. Accuses Ex-House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Paying to Hide ‘Misconduct’
articles.snippet: The Illinois politician is accused of lying to the F.B.I. and structuring cash withdrawals to avoid bank reporting requirements.
articles.abstract: The Illinois politician is accused of lying to the F.B.I. and structuring cash withdrawals to avoid bank reporting requirements.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, has been charged with lying to the F.B.I. and making cash withdrawals from banks in a way that was designed to hide that he was paying $3.5 million to someone for his “misconduct” from years ago, a federal indictment released on Thursday said.

articles.headline: Breaking Silence, Richard Fuld Speaks on Love, Putin and ‘Rocky’
articles.snippet: In his first public appearance since 2008, Mr. Fuld mused about the economy, the Middle East, love and life, but danced around the downfall of his firm, Lehman Brothers.
articles.abstract: In his first public appearance since 2008, Mr. Fuld mused about the economy, the Middle East, love and life, but danced around the downfall of his firm, Lehman Brothers.
articles.lead_paragraph: After nearly seven years of public silence, Richard S. Fuld Jr., the former chief executive of Lehman Brothers, had a lot to say.

articles.headline: ISIS Alternates Stick and Carrot to Control Palmyra
articles.snippet: The militants have alternated between terrorizing residents and courting them in their takeover of the ancient Syrian city.
articles.abstract: The militants have alternated between terrorizing residents and courting them in their takeover of the ancient Syrian city.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hours after they swept into the Syrian city of Palmyra last week, Islamic State militants carried out scores of summary executions, leaving the bodies of victims — including dozens of government soldiers — in the streets.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: China’s Publishers Court America as Its Authors Scorn Censorship
articles.snippet: The Chinese government sent a 500-person delegation from 100 publishing houses to BookExpo America in New York; a few blocks away from the expo, the PEN American Center organized a protest.
articles.abstract: The Chinese government sent a 500-person delegation from 100 publishing houses to BookExpo America in New York; a few blocks away from the expo, the PEN American Center organized a protest.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the Chinese writer Murong Xuecun had the kind of career most novelists dream about. His eight books had sold two million copies in China, and he had amassed more than eight million social media followers.

articles.headline: Political Fights Throw Sand in Gears of S.E.C.
articles.snippet: A political battle has disrupted the case against the Computer Sciences Corporation, forcing on-again, off-again negotiations that at times have imperiled the case altogether.
articles.abstract: A political battle has disrupted the case against the Computer Sciences Corporation, forcing on-again, off-again negotiations that at times have imperiled the case altogether.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than once this year, the Securities and Exchange Commission was close to securing a landmark accounting fraud case. Then it came undone, the result of divisions within the S.E.C. And now the case might be back on track — that is, unless it’s not.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: An Award for Bill Clinton Came With $500,000 for His Foundation
articles.snippet: Bill Clinton agreed to appear at a gala for the model Petra Nemcova’s charity in 2014 after Ms. Nemcova offered a large donation to the Clinton Foundation.
articles.abstract: Bill Clinton agreed to appear at a gala for the model Petra Nemcova’s charity in 2014 after Ms. Nemcova offered a large donation to the Clinton Foundation.
articles.lead_paragraph: To commemorate the 10th anniversary of the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami, Petra Nemcova, a Czech model who survived the disaster by clinging to a palm tree, decided to pull out all the stops for the annual fund-raiser of her school-building charity, the Happy Hearts Fund.

articles.headline: In Europe, Fake Jobs Can Have Real Benefits
articles.snippet: Training at pretend companies is being used to fight long-term unemployment, one of the most pressing problems to emerge from Europe’s long economic crisis.
articles.abstract: Training at pretend companies is being used to fight long-term unemployment, one of the most pressing problems to emerge from Europe’s long economic crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 9:30 a.m. on a sunny weekday, the phones at Candelia, a purveyor of sleek office furniture in Lille, France, rang steadily with orders from customers across the country and from Switzerland and Germany. A photocopier clacked rhythmically while more than a dozen workers processed sales, dealt with suppliers and arranged for desks and chairs to be shipped.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Contracted 0.7% in First Quarter
articles.snippet: The revision downward, which was expected after a brutal winter, underscores the American economy’s seeming inability to generate much momentum.
articles.abstract: The revision downward, which was expected after a brutal winter, underscores the American economy’s seeming inability to generate much momentum.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy got off to an even weaker start this year than first thought, the government reported Friday, as economic activity contracted because of a more dismal trade performance and continued caution by businesses and consumers alike.

articles.headline: Windshield Devices Bring Distracted Driving Debate to Eye Level
articles.snippet: Head-up displays like Navdy’s claim to reduce risk by projecting information from a smartphone into a driver’s line of vision, but some experts worry the additional stimulus will be too distracting.
articles.abstract: Head-up displays like Navdy’s claim to reduce risk by projecting information from a smartphone into a driver’s line of vision, but some experts worry the additional stimulus will be too distracting.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a widely watched YouTube video, a man is driving around Los Angeles when his phone rings. On a small screen mounted on the dashboard, an image of the caller, the man’s mother, appears.

articles.headline: Dany Laferrière, a Guardian of French, Joins the Académie Française
articles.snippet: The writer Dany Laferrière, born in Haiti, is one of the few non-French citizens to become a member of this elite club, a protector of the French language.
articles.abstract: The writer Dany Laferrière, born in Haiti, is one of the few non-French citizens to become a member of this elite club, a protector of the French language.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — He was raised in a small village in Haiti and came of age as a novelist in Montreal, working nights as a janitor after fleeing the Haitian dictatorship of Jean-Claude Duvalier, a.k.a. Baby Doc, in 1976. Now, Dany Laferrière has become one of the few non-French citizens inducted into the Académie Française, the inner sanctum of French letters and august protector of the language.

articles.headline: Aided by the Sea, Israel Overcomes an Old Foe: Drought
articles.snippet: A major national effort to desalinate Mediterranean seawater and to recycle wastewater has provided the country with enough water for all its needs.
articles.abstract: A major national effort to desalinate Mediterranean seawater and to recycle wastewater has provided the country with enough water for all its needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — At the peak of the drought, Shabi Zvieli, an Israeli gardener, feared for his livelihood.

articles.headline: Shrinking Economy? No, but It’s Not Surging Either
articles.snippet: A little appreciated but more reliable measure of the economy suggests growth in the last quarter, although not by very much.
articles.abstract: A little appreciated but more reliable measure of the economy suggests growth in the last quarter, although not by very much.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government reckons that the American economy shrank over the winter, but no one really believes it.

articles.headline: Mutual Fund Giants Vote to Keep the Insiders In
articles.snippet: Fidelity and Vanguard, the fund behemoths, could swing a good number of shareholder votes to expand shareholder rights. So, why don’t they?
articles.abstract: Fidelity and Vanguard, the fund behemoths, could swing a good number of shareholder votes to expand shareholder rights. So, why don’t they?
articles.lead_paragraph: Are Fidelity Investments and the Vanguard Group, two of the nation’s largest mutual fund companies, the skunks at the proxy access party?
